key_insight: A network-aware self-supervised learning framework learns rich, label-free representations of neuronal activity dynamics, enabling scalable high-content phenotypic screening to identify genetic modifiers across diverse neural interventions.
problem_solved: Overcomes the need for extensive labels and naive single-cell/timeseries analyses by jointly modeling network connectivity and temporal dynamics so that subtle, biologically meaningful phenotypes from large activity datasets can be discovered and compared.
method: Train a self-supervised model that is explicitly network-aware to encode spatiotemporal patterns of neuronal activity without manual labels.
Aggregate high-content recordings across multiple perturbations/interventions to produce compact phenotypic embeddings that summarize dynamic responses.
Use embedding shifts and downstream screening workflows to rank and identify candidate genetic modifiers driving changes in activity dynamics.
impact: Demonstrates how representation learning tailored to networked temporal data can turn large, unlabeled neuroscience datasets into actionable biological hypotheses; offers ML practitioners a template for scalable, label-efficient phenotyping applicable to other networked systems.
visual_elements: Pipeline schematic showing: raw neural recordings → network-aware SSL encoder → low-dimensional phenotypic embeddings → candidate ranking
Embedding visualization (UMAP/t-SNE) of activity phenotypes colored by genetic perturbation or intervention
Before/after time-series heatmaps or raster plots illustrating characteristic dynamic changes linked to top candidate modifiers
Bar/volcano-style chart listing prioritized genetic modifiers with effect sizes and confidence
paper_title: Network-aware self-supervised learning enables high-content phenotypic screening for genetic modifiers of neuronal activity dynamics
paper_authors: Parker Grosjean, Kaivalya Shevade, Cuong Nguyen, Sarah Ancheta, Karl Mader
